C. and M. A. Gospel Quintette
comments: The Christian and Missionary Alliance (C. & M.A.) Gospel Singers came together in Cleveland, Ohio, in 1914, due to the efforts of John H. Parker. By 1900, he was living in Cleveland where he soon began performing with something called the Buckeye Quartet. Parker's first contact with the Christian & Missionary Alliance occurred in 1909, and within a few years, he was asked to form a negro quartet named for the organization. The group initially consisted of tenors Parker and Spurgeon R. Jones; baritone Henry D. Hodges, and bass singer Alexander E. Talbert. The unit was expanded to a quintet by the addition of lead tenor Floyd H. Lacy, a postal worker who Parker heard performing with a secular group billed as the Musical Magpies.

name: Pullman Porters Quartet
comments: Prewar Black a capella vocal choir. The Pullman Company, manufacturers of railroad passenger cars, provided in-house musical instruction, which included a cappella quartet singing lessons. The Pullman Company employed a large number of African Americans as porters. The Pullman quartets were a franchise - multiple configurations of singers performing concurrently under the company banner. They put on concerts, either performing live on the radio, or on long haul train routes as a form of passenger entertainment. The men who made the records were billed as the “President’s Own” – the working Pullman porters considered the company’s premier lineup. In 1927, the Pullman Porters Quartette franchise from  Chicago recorded a number of sides for Paramount.

Later on the group would add Derrick Horne, Maulty "Tuff" Jewell IV, Pharis "June Bug" Evans, Jr., Ralph Lofton, Jr., and Terrell Midge Gatlin. They released 42 albums with various labels during their tenure, and 23 albums charted on the Billboard charts, mostly on the Gospel Albums chart.

There he joined The Dumbells, a talented group of Canadian soldiers, who entertained the troops in the trenches from 1917 to 1918, and went on to enjoy national and international success as a highly popular vaudeville act until 1932.

name: Henry Worrall
comments: Musician, composer and artist born in Liverpool, England, resided in Cincinnati, Ohio and Topeka, Kansas, USA His notable compositions, included the celebrated "Sebastopol" in 1856 & "Spanish Fandango" in 1966, gained widespread popularity. His influence on southern rural musicians, particularly through the open D tunings of "Sebastopol" & open G of "Fandango", persisted into the 1920s, and are seen as direct ancestor for common strains found in the delta blues. With later artists like Mississippi John Hurt and Sam McGee reviving and popularising his compositions in the folk music revival of the 1960s. Today, interest in Worrall's music is primarily among fingerstyle guitar enthusiasts, American roots music aficionados, and scholars of country and blues musical traditions.

comments: Indietronica band from Birmingham, known for their musical style incorporating elements from psychedelic rock, krautrock, and musique concrète.

name: Ron Holden
comments: Teen balladeer and songwriter from Seattle, Washington, active from the end of the 1950s till the beginning of the 1960s.

name: Danger Mouse
comments: Musician (piano, keyboards, guitar, bass, drums, percussion), singer, songwriter and record producer, from White Plains, New York

name: Lee Michaels
comments: Rock musician who sings and accompanies himself on organ, piano, or guitar.

name: Matthews' Southern Comfort
comments: Country rock group formed by Iain Matthews, originally as a solo project. When Matthews left, the band went on to release three more albums and several singles as Southern Comfort.

name: Jan Akkerman
comments: Principally a guitarist, he has also recorded on lute and organ. In 1973 Akkerman was voted 'Best Guitarist in The World' by the readers of the UK magazine, Melody Maker.
